post.Title: Craig, Dalston
post.Content:
I spotted a tall fellow heading towards me from amongst the usual Sunday afternoon throng of Kingsland Road, with something long and odd-looking strapped to his bike. In the blink of an eye, he was gone.
Intrigued, I found myself turning around and running down the road to find out what it was...
My target turned out to be a friendly musician called Craig, on the hunt for a new pitch for his street performance. I don't know how he ended up in London from New Zealand, but like any good antipodean, he was travelling with a didgeridoo (and a typewriter).

post.Title: Thoughts on Zen Cycling
post.Content:
If you find yourself become angry whilst riding your bike — whatever the reason — try counting to five before venting spleen.
Usually the car/taxi/bus/pedestrian in question didn't mean it.
And you might even hear an apology that would otherwise have been missed.

post.Title: Ellie, Primrose Hill
post.Content: With the sun on my back and a smile on my face, I was on the prowl around Primrose Hill, and spotted a lovely green bike resting outside Seasame Wholefoods. Out walked Ellie, who proceeded to chat to me energetically as I quizzed her about cycling, and meanwhile slotted a bottle of fruit juice into her bottle cage.

post.Title: Raphael, Primrose Hill
post.Content: A flash of purple wheels caught my attention from the far side of Primrose Hill, and a few minutes later, I caught up with its owner as he stopped to enjoy the sunshine.

post.Title: Bill Cunningham — cycling photographer extraordinaire
post.Content: Shooting New York's street and catwalk fashions for over fourty years, photographer Bill Cunningham's favourite mode of transport has always been his bike. He's now the subject of a fascinating documentary "Bill Cunningham New York", which explores his enormous body of work and paints a portrait of a loveable, if lonely, character. (We're talking about a guy who sleeps on a mattress amongst a room of filing cabinets containing his negatives!) Don't miss Bill's photos of cyclists for the New York Times here. Image credit: Photo credit: First Thought Films / Zeitgeist Films

post.Title: Drink Riding
post.Content:
Swissmiss's post about the  Donkey 6-pack set our bikeheads a-wondering about the possibility of other non-standard bottle cages.

After some extensive research, we're happy to report back on our favourite:

post.Title: Bikes of San Francisco
post.Content: A pictorial guide to the Bikes of San Francisco. I feel a London version coming on... Source with a hat tip to @mertonium for calling it.

post.Title: motherfuckingbike
post.Content:
<iframe width="740" height="406" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/hgCqz3l33kU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Have a think about how you ride... I certainly see one of the angry dudes with mirrors most days.

post.Title: Mylo and Hector, Hackney Downs
post.Content: Graphic designer Hector Pottie and son, Mylo.
post.ImageTitle: Mylo and Hector|Mylo and Hector portrait

post.Title: Brompton
post.Content: A series of images captured by photographer Fred MacGregor inside the Brompton factory. For more behind-the-scenes photos from British manufacturing see Manufacture & Industry

post.Title: Pretty Pink Pashley
post.Content: CycleLove spotted illustrator Hannah crossing Shoreditch Park on a pink Pashley.

post.Title: Mobile disco, Brick Lane
post.Content: Shot by Pete Gloria

post.Title: Tim, Cross Bones, Borough
post.Content: Photographed at the gate of Cross Bones, a post-medieval disused burial ground in The Borough, south London, believed to be the contain the bodies of 15,000 paupers and prostitutes.

post.Title: Haro Master Freestyler
post.Content: CycleLove headed north to meet artist Stuart Free and his Haro Master Freestyler. If 80s BMXs float your boat, this Flickr set contains over three hundred photos of old school freestyle bikes.
post.ImageTitle: Stu's Haro Master Freestyler, Wood Green|Haro closup

post.Title: Camilla, East London
post.Content: Camilla is an illustrator and pattern designer based in Hackney.

post.Title: Tim Davies, Monster bike maker
post.Content: We fell in love with this shot of Tim Davies, a designer/maker based in Hackney Wick. Photograph by Paul Calver for Huck Magazine.

post.Title: Bicycle Film Festival — last call for submissions
post.Content: In 2001, cyclist Brendt Barbur was hit by a bus while riding in New York City. He insisted on turning this negative experience into a positive one, and founded The Bicycle Film Festival, a platform to celebrate the bicycle through music, art and, of course, film. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w3lc-lEYOLk&feature=youtu.be Film-makers, it's not too late to submit your entry for 2012 — roll camera and submit your entry by April 14th.

post.Title: CycleLove presents: Bill Cunningham New York
post.Content:
Celebrate the launch of CycleLove with us, and enjoy a free screening of Bill Cunningham New York, a moving documentary about the octogenarian street-fashion photographer and cyclist. CycleLove presents: Bill Cunningham New York Saturday 21st April from 6pm at Look mum no hands, 49 Old Street, London, EC1V 9HX with vintage DJ set from Auntie Maureen Dress to impress Fashionistas — arrive early to enter (and be photographed) for our “Best-dressed Cyclist” competition — and the chance to win prizes from leading cycle brands like Sögreni and Vulpine.
Event registration for CycleLove launch party + free Bill Cunningham New York screening powered by Eventbrite
If you haven't read the reviews or heard anything about this amazing film yet, here's the trailer: http://youtu.be/NYqiLJBXbss

post.Title: Londoners on Bikes
post.Content: We caught up with Londoners on Bikes, who are doing an amazing job raising the profile of cycle-safety policy at the London Mayoral elections, as they flyered in Angel.  Find out more about the campaign and and follow @LondonersonBikes to stay updated as the election draws closer.

post.Title: A snapshot of Australia's early bike history
post.Content: Incredible archive photographs of Aussie bike culture circa 1890-1950 from the  State Library of New South Wales. From Flickr and the collection of the State Library of New South Wales Via Brain Pickings
post.ImageTitle: Man on bicycle pillioning boy - Bunaloo, NSW|Buti Mashilwane

post.Title: Bicycle Portraits - a photographic book
post.Content: A shot from the stunning "Bicycle Portraits" book — 162 portraits and stories of cyclists photographed by Stan Engelbrecht & Nic Grobler during an epic two year journey across South Africa. The project was successfully funded on Kickstarter last year.

post.Title: London Bike Kitchen
post.Content: Want to fix your bike but don't know where to start? The London Bike Kitchen is a new, open DIY workshop where you can work on your own bike instead of giving it to someone else. Run by Jenni Gwiazdowski, the workshop occupies a once forlorn retail unit in Hoxton, and offers courses in bike maintenance and mechanics to London's fast growing cycling community. Inspired by the bike kitchens of her native California, she aims to "create a space where it is OK to learn; a comfortable environment for everyone" — definitely a vibe that CycleLove picked up on our visit. What bike(s) do you ride? I ride a 2008 women's LeMond, an Alpina Spranghina and have a vintage Claud Butler frame that I will build up someday. The age old question: helmet or no helmet? Depends on the weather, where I'm going or how long I spent on my hair. Sometimes all three. What do you love most about cycling in London? Any favourite rides? I love the fact that my bike can take me anywhere, usually faster than the tube or bus. I enjoy cycling the River Lea. If you were elected Mayor next month, what changes would you make to transport policy to improve life for London's cyclists? In my wildest fantasies I would ban private cars from the road. Public transport only. I believe air pollution is a giant of a problem that affects ALL Londoners - pedestrians, cyclists, and drivers alike.

post.Title: Andreas, London Cyclist
post.Content: One of the inspirations for starting CycleLove was the wealth of amazing bike blogs springing up around London, not least that of Andreas Kambanis, aka the London Cyclist, who I snapped on a slightly grim 'Spring' day outside the Hayward Gallery on the South Bank. What came first, cycling or blogging? Cycling came way before blogging for me. I tried it, loved it and then wanted to know more about it. When I discovered there wasn't really anything out there for the everyday cyclist like myself, I set it up. What bike(s) do you ride? I ride a Raleigh Ti frame that I built up about 8 months ago. It's a great single speed bike that allows me to power my way around London without worrying too much about maintenance and things going wrong. Also, it looks a little old and worn so I think it makes less of a target for thieves. The age old question: helmet or no helmet? For me it's a personal decision but I choose to not wear a helmet. I don't really want to go in to it too much as I feel it's an argument that has been heard so many times over! (Editor's note: We agree. Take the 3,000+ responses on this LFGSS forum thread as a starting point) What do you love most about cycling in London? I cycle in London because I'm lazy. I don't like walking to the tube, waiting for a train and then arriving not exactly at my destination. With the bike I can pull up right next to where I'm meeting someone and I have the freedom to make my own timetable. Plus, London is a gorgeous and fascinating city and I couldn't imagine not seeing it everyday from the saddle. If you were elected Mayor next month, what changes would you make to transport policy to improve life for London's cyclist? As Mayor, I'd force all heavy goods vehicles to have warning devices for when a cyclist is in the danger zone. Also, even though it would make me hugely unpopular, I would extend the congestion charging zone. I believe driving a car in central London is madness.

post.Title: How would you persuade a friend to start cycling?
post.Content:
Those cycle-crazy folk at Bikeminded are on the hunt for a short film to inspire people to change from two feet to two wheels. Which raises the question: how would you persuade a friend or loved one to start cycling? When I moved to London it took me six months to pluck up the courage to start commuting by bike. I couldn't see past the supposedly terrifying buses that I saw cyclists sandwiched between. But with all of my friends nagging me about it, eventually I bought a second-hand number and started cycling. Fast-forward a few months, and I owned three bikes, cycled to work daily, and even rode London to Brighton just for the hell of it. (Non-cyclists, that's something you might not understand, yet...) CycleLove was christened so because I want to get people on bikes by showing them they don't have to be afraid. And, as any good psychologist will tell you, fear is the opposite of love. Armed with some simple facts about the road and holding your position on it, no-one should be intimidated by the thought of cycling. Update: a brilliant suggestion from I Speak Bike:

@cyclelovehq I've been taking friends out on the back of my tandem and showing them their commute route so they can see how easy it is.

— Jude Brosnan (@ISpeakBike) April 19, 2012

post.Title: An invisible bicycle helmet?
post.Content:
Designed by Anna Haupt and Terese Alstin at the Faculty of Engineering at Lund University in Sweden, Hovding is a personal airbag for cyclists.
"Bicycling is something we do every day and there's a sense of freedom that goes with it. Although people are well aware of the risks on the roads, the vast majority are choosing to bicycle without a helmet. When it comes down to it, people do really want to protect their heads in road accidents, but there are limits. It isn't the bicyclists who need to change, it's the product."
Hidden inside a waterproof collar around your neck, Hovding is trigged by abnormal movement, inflating in 1/10 of a second to (almost) encase the wearer's head. However we're not sure what happens if you should land on your face... Cynicism aside however, it's not often that the worlds of cycling safety and cycling fashion collide, and Hovding proves that it is possible to be stylish and protected.

post.Title: Launch party update: it's a sellout
post.Content: An important update tomorrow's (Saturday 21st) launch party at Look mum no hands! If you're lucky enough to have secured tickets, please arrive by 7pm sharp for the Bill Cunningham New York screening. This part of the evening is now sold out, so the earlier you arrive, the more likely you are to nab a seat. Dress to impress: Don't have a ticket for the film? Fear not, the party opens its doors to anyone and everyone between 8.30-11pm, with a vintage DJ set from Auntie Maureen, and reggae from CycleLove's own James Greig. In keeping with the fashion theme of Bill Cunningham New York, we're encouraging (but not forcing) you to DRESS TO IMPRESS. So put on something nice, and head down to Look Mum No Hands on Old Street for a little rockabilly, 50's r & b and 60's boogaloo and soul. Remember, to enter our best-dressed cyclist competition (with amazing prizes from Vulpine and Sogreni), jump on your bike, and arrive around 6-6.30pm, so we have time to take your photo. We'll be blogging all of the photos next week, and the people who get the most Facebook likes will be deemed the winners.

post.Title: David Bennett's Nature Factory
post.Content: "The Nature Factory is a new approach to manufacturing being a small scale mobile factory looking at a future of “hyper-local” production. It is able to with the help of the general public extract from its surroundings, the beach in this instance, raw resources to produce a mouldable material that can be used to make furniture for the beach." This thought-provoking project from designer/engineer/maker David Bennett, based around a bicycle rickshaw, poses some interesting questions about our attitudes to manufacturing materials. Nature Factory produces limecrete, a weak form of concrete, by combining  hydrated Lime and sand/aggregate, which is then cast to make stools. Why do we anthropomorphise and add emotive qualities to some? Categorising them into binary opposites, natural and artificial? As all materials are from the same source, the environment, why are some more emotive or valuable than others? If we were to once again link the source and the material, how would we perceive them? Read more about Nature Factory (PDF)

post.Title: Launch party recap
post.Content:
A huge thanks to everyone who came down to Look Mum No Hands! on Saturday for our first ever event. We were delighted to have a completely full house for the screening of Bill Cunningham New York. Stay tuned for photos from the best-dressed cyclist competition and more shots of an amazing tall bike in action (scroll down for a sneak peak)...

Had great time at launch party for @cyclelovehq watching the Bill Cunningham New York screening, he is truly amazing person!!!!

@LadyVelo I know, me too! Loved the film, was so gorgeous. Bill seems like such a sweetie! @1ookmumnohands @cyclelovehq

post.Title: My Raleigh
post.Content: I shot a few test images yesterday for tonight's launch photo-shoot, of which this is probably my favourite. She's a bit of a mish-mash of parts (including a beautiful Italmanubri quill stem), and none of the components even match, but the colour always makes me smile.

post.Title: Wren bicycles — small and beautiful
post.Content:
If you're looking for a new compact bike with a vintage twist,  this beauty from Wren Bicycles might fit the bill.
"The Wren Original combines the charm of vintage style with the practicality of contemporary design and components. Purpose-built for city cycling, this sturdy 3-speed model is equipped with bespoke luggage racks to carry all you need for your day."
According to Sargent and Co (North London specialists in classic road bikes but now selling new bikes too) it doesn't ride like it's small, or twitch like some of its competitors. With a Brooks sprung saddle and removable racks, it's practical too.

post.Title: Julian, Kath and Harlow, Londoners on Bikes
post.Content: As the election race between Boris and Ken hots up in London, Londoners on Bikes are likewise stepping up their campaign to raise awareness of cycle safety issues, and have cleverly targeted the cute-vote by enlisting their pets. On an unrelated note, I've decided to put my pet-photography career plans on hold, for now. Too much like hard work.

post.Title: Louie-Blu, outside Look Mum No Hands
post.Content: We spotted Louie-Blu getting his BMX fixed at Look Mum No Hands on Old Street. Louie, if you're reading this, please click here to email us, so we can send you a limited edition CycleLove poster!

post.Title: Judge the first CycleLove best-dressed competition
post.Content: Due to the rain (and possibly irrate Addison Lee taxi drivers in bus lanes), the turnout for our inaugral best-dressed competition at our launch party was lower than hoped. However, we still need you to vote for your favourite by clicking the 'Like' button. First prize is a beautifully minimal bike bell from Sogreni — so, check out the photos below and get voting! UPDATE: Voting ends Tuesday 1st May at 10am. UPDATE: Voting is over, and the winner is Petor. Well dressed, sir!

post.Title: Neil, tokyobike
post.Content: Founded in 2002 in a sleepy  Tokyo suburb, tokyobike is a small bike manufacturer which has recently opened stores in Berlin, London and Paris. Their bikes are beautifully simple, with a compact frame, and (something that's not immediately obvious in photos) smaller than usual wheels. The result is a light and manoeuvrable  bike that's perfectly suited for city-riding. Possibly the most photogenic bike store that CycleLove has yet encountered, tokyobike London is cannily located at the cycling/design hub of Tabernacle Street in Shoreditch. The store isn't just about bikes though, as you can also buy a range of beautiful Japanese products, sourced from craftspeople around their Japanese headquarters.   We asked Neil, co-owner/director of tokyobike UK, about cycling in London... What bike(s) do you ride? A tokyobike CS - colour depends on my mood! The age old question: helmet or no helmet? I'm a recent convert to helmets - essential kit. What do you love most about cycling in London? Any favourite rides? It's the only way to get around. London is too big a city to cover on foot and too great a city to miss out on stuck behind a windscreen. The five minute cycle from my flat in the Brunswick Centre to Lantana (favourite cafe) on a Sunday morning is up there. Riding through the grand squares of Islington, getting on the the Grand Union and stopping at Towpath Cafe for breakfast is pretty good. But if I have to pick one it would be the Tweed Run - London at its very best. If you were elected Mayor, what changes would you make to transport policy to improve life for London's cyclists? Ban private cars from central london (except for disabled people etc..). I love to drive but its pretty obvious London would be a better place if it became a cycle city.

post.Title: Magnetic bike lights?
post.Content:
The bike boffins at Copenhagan Parts are developing a range of magnetic bike lights, which automagically turn on when attached to a steel frame (take that, carbon).
"We are launching two versions – Randonneur and Lode. Randonneur has a body of machined aluminium and is polished to give a very classic finish. Lode has a silicone rubber outer, available in a range of striking colours. Both versions come in a small and cool package, made from recycled materials, that can be used to store the lights and to display them in-store. Both are extremely compact and use battery-driven LED light sources. The lens is designed to illuminate from the sides as well as straight-on to increase visibility. The fact that they can be placed anywhere on the frame without fittings also makes it possible to use multiple sets to further aid visibility to other road users."
You can pre-order the lights here in advance of their Autumn 2012 release.

post.Title: Meditation at gunpoint
post.Content: "When I’m balanced on two thin wheels at 30 miles an hour, gauging distance, adjusting course, making hundreds of unconscious calculations every second, that idiot chatterbox in my head is kept too busy to get a word in. I’ve heard people say the same thing about rock-climbing: how it shrinks your universe to the half-inch of rock surface immediately in front of you, this crevice, that toehold. Biking is split-second fast and rock-climbing painstakingly slow, but both practices silence the noise of the mind and render self-consciousness blissfully impossible. You become the anonymous hero of that old story, Man versus the Universe. Your brain’s glad to finally have a real job to do, instead of all that trivial busywork. You are all action, no deliberation. You are forced, under pain of death, to quit all that silly ideation and pay attention. It’s meditation at gunpoint." Taken from Tim Kreider's article for the New York Times — Cycle of Fear Illustration by Marcus Nyblom

post.Title: Visualised: bike use in Budapest over 24 hours
post.Content: Question: what do patterns of use for commuting cyclists look like? Innovation lab Kitchen Budapest have mapped over 62,000km of data from the Urbancyclr app in an attempt to find out (although some may find the result slightly cryptic).

post.Title: How to get on a tall bike
post.Content: Ever wondered how people get onto their tall bikes? Petor (bike mechanic at the London Bike Kitchen), and reputably a man who owns more bikes than he has outfits to go with them, gave me a demonstration... PS. Check out this video of a 12-foot tall bike PPS. Then check out this video of a tall bike world record attempt

post.Title: Emma — a slow cyclist
post.Content:
My name’s Emma and I’m a slow cyclist. Not for me this dashing about in head-to-toe Lycra, weaving in and out of traffic and pedestrians, trying to make it everywhere in record speed. I used to be that way, but over the past six years my attitude has altered hugely. I’ve changed my bike, my style and my attitude – and I couldn’t be happier. I’ve ditched the leggings and the fluoro jacket, which is great but it’s also meant ditching my all-weather attitude. I hold my hands up now and say I rarely cycle in the rain – although judging by the past few weeks, I may have to revise this if I want to get any cycling done this summer. My biking fashion isn’t the only change, mind you. I’ve also done a u-turn in my style of cycling. I’ve invested in a beautiful red upright with just three gears so, I have little choice about my top speed. This is partly to accommodate my growing baby bump, but that’s it’s also just one factor in a whole load of brilliant reasons to cycle slowly in London. Turning down the speed makes me feel much safer on two wheels – not to be underestimated when you’re responsible for the safe carrying of an unborn child! I feel I can react more easily to drivers, spot potential hazards ahead and generally get out of the way of trouble. I used to feel that was more likely when zipping about, but now I’m convinced that you’d be in trouble before you had time to react. Slow and steady is no bad thing when it comes to getting there in one piece. Most of all, the new way of cycling gives me time to look around, appreciate my surroundings, notice the seasons, the smells and the noises of this great, big hulking city that I love with a passion. I’m not saying that you’re oblivious to these sublties if you’re speeding along, but you definitely miss a lot. I’ve learned not to underestimate the simple pleasure of the year’s first whiff of mown grass in Burgess Park, or the inescapable smell of charcoal that signals great swathes of south London from Elephant to East Dulwich are having barbecues on a balmy summer’s evening. I love noticing unexplored streets and watching construction projects rise up before my eyes. Nothing beats wrapping up against the autumn chill and pedaling through a misty park or setting out on a crisp, frosty morning with the sun low in the sky. I’ve always had snatches of feeling transported back to my youth by travelling by bike but this happens more and more these days, thanks to the Birdie, my more stylish attire and a calm easy riding style. In my six years of being a London cyclist, I’ve never felt happier in the saddle, and, with baby Haines on the way, I can’t wait to introduce a whole new generation of bikers to its pleasures.
Guest post by Emma Simkins iheartbikes.squarespace.com @EmmaS_MC

post.Title: Wacky Races at Herne Hill Velodrome
post.Content: Ok, so Muttley wasn't really involved, but I did stumble across an amazing penny farthing race at Herne Hill Velodrome last weekend. The track is one of the oldest in the world, having been built in 1891, and even hosted the track cycling events in the 1948 Olympics.

post.Title: Giro Reverb
post.Content: Giro have launched a new range of 'classic' helmets for urban cyclists, Reverb, which boasts a self-adjusting fit system and comes in a range of colours (we're not sure about the orange/black combo though). This promo video features artist Chris McNally riding the sunny streets of San Francisco...

post.Title: Alvin Smith
post.Content: These beautiful machines are Paris Galibiers (correction: Alvin is photographed with a Tour de France) and part of classic cycle enthusiast Alvin Smith's collection. The bikes were built in Stoke Newington between 1936 and 1952 — their unusual frame being designed to give a smoother ride by absorbing road shocks.

post.Title: Ritchie, New Orleans
post.Content: The first word which sprung to mind to describe this bike was 'customised', but somehow it doesn't quite do the machine justice. With electric guitars for pedals, a drinks holder, and a whole menagerie of other instruments, it's one hell of jazzy ride. It belongs to artist and chef Ritchie Jordan, who's been car-free for 5 years, and invited CycleLove along to the NOLA social ride, a weekly ride/gathering for bike lovers in New Orleans.

post.Title: Statue of Liberty, New York
post.Content: I couldn't have hoped for a better way to start my trip around the USA than with this photo. God bless America!

post.Title: On-street bike parking in the Big Apple
post.Content: On-street bike parking, like this well considered spot in Brooklyn, seems to be popping up all over New York. I'm sure it could work in the UK too (at the small cost of further enraging the "but cyclists don't pay road tax!" camp).

post.Title: Jim, Alpine Bikeman
post.Content: Jim works at the Alpine Bikeman store in Texas — more photos of the shop and owner John Elsbury to follow tomorrow.

post.Title: John, Alpine Bikeman
post.Content: Raleigh dealer and obsessive bike hoarder John Elsbery owns Alpine Bikeman. We spotted some beautiful old cruisers and a tandem lurking in the back-yard, and had a sneak peak of a custom electric bike that John was working on.

post.Title: Bike-centric junction, Tucson, Arizona
post.Content: What would happen if bikes were given priority over cars at busy intersections? The city of Tucson is chasing the "platinum" level of bicycle-friendliness awards from the League of American Bicyclists, which would put it in the same company as other bike-friendly cities such as Portland, Oregon. At this junction, the cycle lane occupies most of the road, and continues on into a dedicated cycle-route which allows riders to cruise safely on into town. Love it.

post.Title: Santa Monica & Los Angeles
post.Content: LA turned out to be more bike-friendly than I expected...

post.Title: Zee Unsh, Brooklyn
Big hills, small bike... San Francisco
Gary, Pedals for Progress
post.Content: What to do with that unwanted old bike in your back yard? Pedals for Progress have recycled over 130,000 bikes destined for US landfills, improving lives in the developing world by shipping them to developing countries like Nicaragua, Ghana and Vietnam. Their business model goes beyond just the bikes, sewing machines are also recycled, and spare parts sent with the bikes to ensure that the new owner has everything he or she needs to maintain their new (old) bike. Find out about Pedals for Progress bike collections process and collection schedule, or make a donation.

post.Title: Schwinn Lovers, Dumbo, New York
post.Content: Close to melting in the scorching New York sun, I took refuge under the Brooklyn Bridge, and spotted a cute pair of pink and blue Schwinns. PS. Guys, in the heat I completely forgot to get your names! If you're reading this, drop me a line and I'll update this post for you.

post.Title: Tel Aviv BMX
post.Content: via idobartel

post.Title: Matt, Williamsburg, New York
post.Content: Bumped into the keyboard player from Talibam!, Matt Mottel. He swore his bike wasn't meant to match his shirt but I don't believe him.

post.Title: Submit to CycleLove via Instagram
post.Content: Follow CycleLove on Instagram and submit your bike photos to this blog by tagging them #cyclelovehq — easy!
